text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with butter puff biscuit dough
that's right if puff pastry and biscuit
dough had a baby this would be the
result and I know a lack of reproductive
organs makes that scenario impossible
but what's not impossible is the dough
that comes out remarkably similar to a
puff pastry using a much simpler much
less fussy procedure so this is the
dough I tease during our Apple Rose's
pastry video and I promised I'd show you
how to make it so here we go and it's
going to sound a little odd but before
we make the dough we have to make a
dough and to do that believe it or not
we're just using two ingredients so in
the bowl of our stand mixer I'm going to
add some self-rising flour along with
some cold fresh water and using our
dough hook attachment we will need that
for a couple minutes until we have a
nice soft very very slightly elastic
dough and one reason this method is
going to be much simpler than a
traditional puff pastry is that the base
for that is actually a yeast dough which
is slightly more involved at plus you
have to wait for it to rise today we
will mix that up and when it's done it
should look and feel something like this
and once that set what we'll do is we'll
wrap this up because we need to chill
this before it gets anywhere near the
butter and yes I know we have some air
trapped in there don't be alarmed this
is going to get rolled flat anyway so
we'll wrap it up and we'll pop it in the
fridge for at least 30 minutes and get
it ready for the first application of
butter oh there's going to be more than
one application so we will chill our
dough after which we can pull it out
unwrap it and roll it into a rectangle
about a half inch thick and as usual
we're just going to use enough flour so
it doesn't stick to the rolling pin or
our hands or the table and like I said
we're going to roll that out into a
rectangular shape which is going to be
approximately I'm not sure how many
inches by I don't know how many inches
that is and the point I'm trying to make
is it doesn't matter as long as it's a
rectangle and anywhere close to about a
half inch thick we can move on to the
next step which will be the grading of
the butter and not just any butter
frozen butter so I put a stick of butter
in the freezer and with the help of a
cheese grater I'm going to grate on just
over half a stick of butter and by the
way when you're done with this put that
butter back in the freezer for the next
application and once that's grated on
we'll take a piece of plastic wrap and
use that to gently press that butter
into the dough and when I did this one
thing I notice is that the butter stuck
the plastic so what you will want to do
is flower that plastic first and you'll
see we do it the next time it does work
better but anyway well great on and
press down some butter
at which point we're going to take our
bench scraper and give this the classic
trifold so we'll fold that third over
this way and on the other side up over
this way which some people will call a
letter fold instead of a trifold same
difference and what we accomplished
there is turning one layer of butter
into two but that's not even close to
enough layers of butter so we'll put a
little more flour down and we'll roll
that into another rectangle shape and I
don't want you to be concerned with the
exact thickness or exact shape and size
of this rectangle the only thing that
really matters is that you're able to
fold it because all we're trying to
accomplish here is going from two layers
of butter to six layers of butter so
we'll give this the exact same try fold
in one tip you always want to brush off
any excess flour before you do these
foldings and Rowling's because what will
happen is that dough won't stick
together to be like flour in the way so
that kind of thing right there is the
difference between a pro baker and
posers like me but anyway despite my
poor technique I was able to fold it and
I'm going to give it another rolling to
approximately an inch thick at which
point we're going to wrap that in
plastic and put that back in the fridge
to chill thoroughly before moving on to
more butter and the creation of many
many more layers and by the way I
believe the official term for what we're
doing here making these layers with the
butter in the dough is called lamination
so keep that mind just in case you ever
end up at a pastry base game show it
could happen but anyway I just killed
enough time while you watch me wrap that
up and we'll transfer that into the
fridge for 30 minutes at which point
we'll take it out and continue on and
unless I've lost count I believe we have
six layers of butter right now which I
decided to increase before applying the
rest of the butter so stop me if you've
heard this one before but we're going to
roll this out into a rectangle and do
another trifold which should then give
us 18 layers of butter and by the way
that's as far as I'm counting because
this gets into the hundreds although I
do fully expect you guys to continue
counting so we'll roll that into a
rectangle and we'll give it the old
trifold and yes it is more of a square
than a rectangle but again it doesn't
matter as long as you can fold it
creating like I said eighteen layers and
then yet again we will roll it back out
into a rectangular shape
about a half inch thick and I guess
since my rectangle is 2 square last time
I overcompensated and did a little bit
of an extra long rectangle but as I keep
saying doesn't matter so we're going to
roll that out and then grab our butter
from the freezer and grate that over
just like we did the first time and
speaking of the first time I should have
mentioned we probably don't want to do
our butter all the way to the edge so
once you're done grading you can kind of
sweep that butter in a little bit from
the edges and once we've done that we
will again press it down with some
plastic wrap but this time as promised
we're going to coat that with a little
bit of flour first and that did work
much better and then and I'm sure you
did not see this coming
we're going to give it another try fold
and then once that fold is done we'll
give it a little rolling like we did
before to kind of press everything
together and I was actually thinking of
stopping right here but I got greedy and
I decided I wanted to double my layers
so I folded it in half which according
to my calculations we've give me twice
as many layers as I had before and once
I had done that and realized how easy I
just doubled my layers I did it again
and there was no hoops involved except
that because of my greediness I sort of
lost my perfect symmetry which I'd be
lying if I said bothered me that much
but things were relatively precise until
this point but anyway that last fold
concluded the buttering and folding
portion of the program and at this point
all we need to do is wrap that up and
chill it thoroughly before we use it I'd
say at least a half hour but probably a
couple hours is better and once it is
thoroughly chilled we can pull that out
and pretty much use it for anything we
would use puff pastry for so I went
ahead and rolled out my dough and cut
some round shapes so I could bake these
in testan and once these were cut and
placed on a lined baking sheet I gave
them a little bit of an egg wash as well
as some Demerara sugar because I'd
actually hope to use these in our
Strawberry Shortcake video which ended
up being a complete failure because as I
learned cold puff pastry is almost
impossible to cut with a spoon but
anyway you will read about that sad tale
I'm a blog post let's get back to the
part that wasn't a failure so I went
ahead and I popped those in a 400 degree
oven for about 18 minutes at which point
they look like this that looks
like puff pastry and it pretty much was
so let me tear one of these apart which
happened without barely touching it by
the way that would be the not brushing
the flour off but anyway as I separate
these layers you can kind of see what
happened we basically have layered dough
layer butter layer dough layer butter
and that happens I'm estimating a couple
hundred times of course I still had to
bite into double check and it was very
good an extremely croissant like so to
summarize I was incredibly happy with
how this came out
and I forget who said if I knew I was
going to live this long I would have
taken better care of myself but I was
kind of reminded of that because if I'd
known how good this was going to come
out I would have organized the steps a
little more precisely and paid a lot
more attention to the exact ingredient
amounts but I didn't so we may or may
not fine-tune this in the future but in
the meantime I really do hope you give
this a try so head over to food wishes
comm for all the ingredient amounts and
more info as usual and as always enjoy
